channel.name: Managing snarkyjs import on the frontend

messages.content: good question, using the toplevel await within snarky itself also broke compatibility with some frontend stacks, i tried setting up an ui recently and gave up after half a day of toying with it
i had luck using Vite for top level await support, no luck with Parcel unfortunately.

Ah, I've been using vite, and not had problems with top level await!  But I'd still like to manage where and when it gets called.

As an example, if you navigate directly to https://mina-arena.45930.xyz/how-to-play, it does not require snarkyJS and loads fine.  If you navigate directly to https://mina-arena.45930.xyz/enter it does require snarkyJS and imports it before rendering any HTML.  _BUT_ it only requires snarkyJS via a function like I linked above which never gets called unless a user requests to generate a new account.  I'd like not to import snarkyJS until the user makes that decision.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/import

I suppose this is supposed to work, and maybe more related to svelte-kit, vite, or some other tool I'm using rather than the basic JS.
what does your transpiled code look like? are you using polyfillDynamicImport?
this might help: https://stackoverflow.com/a/72479802

embeds.title: Vue + Vite + Rollup: Dynamic import not working on production build
embeds.description:
I'm trying to use Vite with dynamic-import Vue SFCs, but it does not work on production build.
There is stackblitz example:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/vitejs-vite-ant1g2?file=src/main.ts
Test comm...

messages.content: UI tooling gets worse every year i swear
That's interesting, but "luckily" it's failing in dev and prod
I fixed this by triggering the import in a webworker so it doesn’t block the ui thread
It also seems like it’s blocking when you do a top level import because if I do that and open a nextjs page it becomes white for a split second before rendering my UI
That’s why I decided to do a dynamic import in a webworker

didnt snarky at some point move all ‘heavy work’ to a prover automatically? it wasnt the case 6 months ago but i believe this was ‘fixed’ in recent releases - but the top level import kinda breaks that
Yeah that's a good point.  I was struggling to get web workers to work as expected in my app earlier, but now that I'm "off the clock", I'm sure it will just work 🙂
Lol it`s very strange as for me. Especially considering what I thought that similar "tricks" handled by library itself.
I guess putting snarkyJS work in a web worker is kind of the official recommendation.  It's just on devs to get every combination of frontend tooling to work together.
I’m using comlink, works locally just had an issue in my prod build but didn’t have time to look into it yet
https://github.com/devarend/mina-playground/blob/main/src/webworkers/worker.ts

messages.content: It’s actually a similar action to generate keys
Using it here: https://github.com/devarend/mina-playground/blob/main/src/components/modal/DeployModal.tsx

embeds.title: mina-playground/src/components/modal/DeployModal.tsx at main · deva...
embeds.description: Contribute to devarend/mina-playground development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: Wow what a similar function lol!
Just add a loading state in your component and it should work

Dynamic import not working as intended is really unfortunate.

What do y'all think - should we bring back isReady?

To provide some history: when we refactored how snarkyjs launches its own internal workers, it turned out that 'await isReady' was no longer needed in the nodejs version. So I thought - would be nice to get rid of it entirely, assuming web tooling has adapted to top level await. Then you can just import and use snarkyjs without extra complexity that normal libraries don't have.

One thing about snarkyjs that's different is the large amount of top level computation it does, which takes 1-2sec. I looked into it and think we can get rid of most of that import time. So, I wonder how the equation changes when import time went down to, say, 200ms - would you still want to keep isReady not render-blocking, or would you just await it at the top level?
@45930 @maht0rz wdyt ^^
i’d be interested in learning what takes the 2 seconds on import first 👀

Mainly converting strings to Ocaml field elements, and doing slow Poseidon hashes to compute hash prefixes (for hash domain separation), and also doing hashes to compute dummy account / account update objects
It's all in the OCaml code base, and mostly seems unnecessary or at least unnecessarily slow
That said, just parsing and JIT compiling the large JS of Ocaml bundle takes non trivial time which I can't optimize away, and which can be made (used to be) non render blocking with isReady

so in order to use any of the synchronous APIs like Field(0), we have to setup some stuff behind the scenes. 

Now the question is if isReady is blocking while it happens - if it freezes the UI thread for the duration of the promise. If yes, then it belongs to the web worker in all cases.

What I like about isready is I’m used to it and it works for me.  I also believe web workers makes the most sense but we’ve had trouble getting those to work as expected.  As discussed in Matej’s other thread.  Makes sense to me to just get tighter with that pattern.

mmm so with TLA, its blocking and you have no control over it - even if its just 300ms not 2000ms. With isReady, you can at least control when that blocking action will happen.

If we do asynchronous imports to control when the blocking TLA will be triggered, we have to roll our own isReady solution to keep track of the import + some clunky management of the imported references
Yes it's blocking
Vite works well and we configuried webpack to work with top level await when generating a React project with the `zkApp cli`.
Did you ever get web workers to run with Svelte?
We should probably rewrite tutorial 4(web worker ui example) in at least Svelte and Vue(Nuxt) to have examples in different frameworks people can reference.
Fwiw, my longer term vision would be to make proving and similar stuff non blocking - have snarkyjs run everything in a worker. I hope that devs would no longer need to deal with workers themselves
I got this top-level-await after updating the snarkyjs to 0.12.1. How can I solve this?
@Martin maybe try what the error message says - enable top level await
I don't know where to put it
@gregor
Me neither
Probably in your webpack config?
@noutdev  I have changed it by using craco

@Martin you can create a react(NextJS) ui project with all the configurations to work with o1js(fka SnarkyJS) along with  a smart contract with the `zkApp-cli` https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/how-to-write-a-zkapp
